_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



For further information concerning this executive summary or other elements of the Risk Management Program please contact Marty Hanshew, Unit Supervisor at:



Simplot Grower Solutions

1013 Old River Road

Umatilla, OR 97882



Phone: (509) 547-5960



Policies and Guidelines

It is the policy of the J.R. Simplot Company (Environmental Policy Statement EN 01.1) to manufacture, handle, store and dispose of all substances safely and in compliance with the requirements of federal, state and local environmental laws while reducing the risks to human health, safety and the environment. Each manager\Supervisor is expected to responsibly implement this policy, and each employee is expected to comply fully with the spirit, as well as the letter of this policy. The Company will assure that the environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and standards applicable to its products and operations are known and obeyed by employees.



The J.R. Simplot Company Guideline (Safety & Health Policy SA 001) states that the Company is committed to reducing incidents or occurrences in the workplace that result in human injury, illness, or death, and/or destruction or loss to the corporation's assets and to be in compliance with all laws and regulations governing workplace safety. It is, therefore, our intent to provide a safe work environment and to protect the corporation's assets. This guideline applies to all groups and separate operating entities of the J.R. Simplot Company. Emergency plans shall be developed for each operating unit outlining the practices and procedures for emergency medical care, fire response, evacuation, or other emergencies. Each group shall develop and implement appropriate programs for initial and ongoing safety and loss prevention training of employees.





Regulated Substance(s)



At this J.R. Simplot Company retail agriculture fertilizer location, Anhydrous Ammonia is only present in railcars or trucks. There is no permanent st

orage at this location.  Occasionally a contractor comes to the site to blend a non-hazardous fertilizer with the analysis 10-34-0 or 11-37-0.  The contractor connects to full trucks or railcars of ammonia and railcars of phosphoric acid to their batching unit.  Procedures and training for this process is the responsibility of the contractor, as Simplot employees are not involved with any Ammonia handling. 



Accidental Release Program

         

This Anhydrous ammonia facility implemented the provisions of the State of Oregon "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" regulation and the "Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Ammonia " as published by American National Standards Institute and Compressed Gas Association (ANSI/CGA G-2.1), and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  



Five Year Accident History



In the past five years there have been no accidental releases at this site. 



Emergency Response Program



This facility has developed a written emergency contingency plan (Integrated Contingency Plan). The plan addresses the regulations concerning emergency plans as mandated under: OSHA 29 CFR - 1910.38, 1910.119, and 1910.120, EPA 40 CFR - part 264 subpart D, part 265 subpart D, part 68 and 279.52, DOT/RSPA-FRP - 49 CFR part 194. Elements within this plan include employee training, SARA Title III reporting requirements and community right to know, pre-emergency planning, and emergency response planning.



Program Ownership and Responsibility



The J.R. Simplot Company is the owner and responsible party for implementation and maintenance of the Risk Management Program according to 40 CFR 68; including all elements required within Program Level 2 guidelines outlined in 40 CFR 68.170.  



The contracted mobile pipe reactor company is the owner and responsible party for implementation and maintenance of the Process Safety Management Program g

uidelines outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Safety and Environmental programs are very dynamic; since this is an ongoing process, changes toward improvement are evaluated and implemented periodically. The need for improvement is identified by facility employee inputs, inspections and audits which are performed regularly at this facility.
